segment.source: Learn how to integrate images into your app, including how to use the APIs of the two main XAML classes, Image and ImageBrush.
segment.target: Learn how to integrate images into your app, including how to use the APIs of the two main XAML classes, Image and ImageBrush.

segment.source: Images and image brushes
segment.target: Images and image brushes

segment.source: Images and image brushes
segment.target: Images and image brushes

segment.source: To display an image, you can use either the Image object or the ImageBrush object.
segment.target: To display an image, you can use either the Image object or the ImageBrush object.

segment.source: An Image object renders an image, and an ImageBrush object paints another object with an image.
segment.target: An Image object renders an image, and an ImageBrush object paints another object with an image.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Image class
segment.target: Image class

segment.source: Source property
segment.target: Source property

segment.source: ImageBrush class
segment.target: ImageBrush class

segment.source: ImageSource property
segment.target: ImageSource property

segment.source: Are these the right elements?
segment.target: Are these the right elements?

segment.source: Use an Image element to display a stand-alone image in your app.
segment.target: Use an Image element to display a stand-alone image in your app.

segment.source: Use an ImageBrush to apply an image to another object.
segment.target: Use an ImageBrush to apply an image to another object.

segment.source: Uses for an ImageBrush include decorative effects for text, or tiled backgrounds for controls or layout containers.
segment.target: Uses for an ImageBrush include decorative effects for text, or tiled backgrounds for controls or layout containers.

segment.source: You can control how the image is stretched, aligned, and tiled, enabling you to produce patterns and other effects.
segment.target: You can control how the image is stretched, aligned, and tiled, enabling you to produce patterns and other effects.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: Create an image
segment.target: Create an image

segment.source: Image
segment.target: Image

segment.source: This example shows how to create an image by using the Image object.
segment.target: This example shows how to create an image by using the Image object.

segment.source: Here's the rendered Image object.
segment.target: Here's the rendered Image object.

segment.source: Example of an image element
segment.target: Example of an image element

segment.source: In this example, the Source property specifies the location of the image that you want to display.
segment.target: In this example, the Source property specifies the location of the image that you want to display.

segment.source: You can set the Source by specifying an absolute URL (for example, http://contoso.com/myPicture.jpg) or by specifying a URL that is relative to your app packaging structure.
segment.target: You can set the Source by specifying an absolute URL (for example, http://contoso.com/myPicture.jpg) or by specifying a URL that is relative to your app packaging structure.

segment.source: For our example, we put the "licorice.jpg" image file in the root folder of our project and declare project settings that include the image file as content.
segment.target: For our example, we put the "licorice.jpg" image file in the root folder of our project and declare project settings that include the image file as content.

segment.source: ImageBrush
segment.target: ImageBrush

segment.source: With the ImageBrush object, you can use an image to paint an area that takes a Brush object.
segment.target: With the ImageBrush object, you can use an image to paint an area that takes a Brush object.

segment.source: For example, you can use an ImageBrush for the value of the Fill property of an Ellipse or the Background property of a Canvas.
segment.target: For example, you can use an ImageBrush for the value of the Fill property of an Ellipse or the Background property of a Canvas.

segment.source: The next example shows how to use an ImageBrush to paint an Ellipse.
segment.target: The next example shows how to use an ImageBrush to paint an Ellipse.

segment.source: Here's the Ellipse painted by the ImageBrush.
segment.target: Here's the Ellipse painted by the ImageBrush.

segment.source: An Ellipse painted by an ImageBrush.
segment.target: An Ellipse painted by an ImageBrush.

segment.source: Stretch an image
segment.target: Stretch an image

segment.source: If you don't set the Width or Height values of an Image, it is displayed with the dimensions of the image specified by the Source.
segment.target: If you don't set the Width or Height values of an Image, it is displayed with the dimensions of the image specified by the Source.

segment.source: Setting the Width and Height creates a containing rectangular area in which the image is displayed.
segment.target: Setting the Width and Height creates a containing rectangular area in which the image is displayed.

segment.source: You can specify how the image fills this containing area by using the Stretch property.
segment.target: You can specify how the image fills this containing area by using the Stretch property.

segment.source: The Stretch property accepts these values, which the Stretch enumeration defines:
segment.target: The Stretch property accepts these values, which the Stretch enumeration defines:

segment.source: None: The image doesn't stretch to fill the output dimensions.
segment.target: None: The image doesn't stretch to fill the output dimensions.

segment.source: Be careful with this Stretch setting: if the source image is larger than the containing area, your image will be clipped, and this usually isn't desirable because you don't have any control over the viewport like you do with a deliberate Clip.
segment.target: Be careful with this Stretch setting: if the source image is larger than the containing area, your image will be clipped, and this usually isn't desirable because you don't have any control over the viewport like you do with a deliberate Clip.

segment.source: Uniform: The image is scaled to fit the output dimensions.
segment.target: Uniform: The image is scaled to fit the output dimensions.

segment.source: But the aspect ratio of the content is preserved.
segment.target: But the aspect ratio of the content is preserved.

segment.source: This is the default value.
segment.target: This is the default value.

segment.source: UniformToFill: The image is scaled so that it completely fills the output area but preserves its original aspect ratio.
segment.target: UniformToFill: The image is scaled so that it completely fills the output area but preserves its original aspect ratio.

segment.source: Fill: The image is scaled to fit the output dimensions.
segment.target: Fill: The image is scaled to fit the output dimensions.

segment.source: Because the content's height and width are scaled independently, the original aspect ratio of the image might not be preserved.
segment.target: Because the content's height and width are scaled independently, the original aspect ratio of the image might not be preserved.

segment.source: That is, the image might be distorted to completely fill the output area.
segment.target: That is, the image might be distorted to completely fill the output area.

segment.source: An example of stretch settings.
segment.target: An example of stretch settings.

segment.source: Crop an image
segment.target: Crop an image

segment.source: You can use the Clip property to clip an area from the image output.
segment.target: You can use the Clip property to clip an area from the image output.

segment.source: You set the Clip property to a Geometry.
segment.target: You set the Clip property to a Geometry.

segment.source: Currently, non-rectangular clipping is not supported.
segment.target: Currently, non-rectangular clipping is not supported.

segment.source: The next example shows how to use a RectangleGeometry as the clip region for an image.
segment.target: The next example shows how to use a RectangleGeometry as the clip region for an image.

segment.source: In this example, we define an Image object with a height of 200.
segment.target: In this example, we define an Image object with a height of 200.

segment.source: A RectangleGeometry defines a rectangle for the area of the image that will be displayed.
segment.target: A RectangleGeometry defines a rectangle for the area of the image that will be displayed.

segment.source: The Rect property is set to "25,25,100,150", which defines a rectangle starting at position "25,25" with a width of 100 and a height of 150.
segment.target: The Rect property is set to "25,25,100,150", which defines a rectangle starting at position "25,25" with a width of 100 and a height of 150.

segment.source: Only the part of the image that is within the area of the rectangle is displayed.
segment.target: Only the part of the image that is within the area of the rectangle is displayed.

segment.source: Here's the clipped image on a black background.
segment.target: Here's the clipped image on a black background.

segment.source: An Image object cropped by a RectangleGeometry.
segment.target: An Image object cropped by a RectangleGeometry.

segment.source: Apply an opacity
segment.target: Apply an opacity

segment.source: You can apply an Opacity to an image so that the image is rendered semi-translucent.
segment.target: You can apply an Opacity to an image so that the image is rendered semi-translucent.

segment.source: The opacity values are from 0.0 to 1.0 where 1.0 is fully opaque and 0.0 is fully transparent.
segment.target: The opacity values are from 0.0 to 1.0 where 1.0 is fully opaque and 0.0 is fully transparent.

segment.source: This example shows how to apply an opacity of 0.5 to an Image.
segment.target: This example shows how to apply an opacity of 0.5 to an Image.

segment.source: Here's the rendered image with an opacity of 0.5 and a black background showing through the partial opacity.
segment.target: Here's the rendered image with an opacity of 0.5 and a black background showing through the partial opacity.

segment.source: An Image object with an opacity of .5.
segment.target: An Image object with an opacity of .5.

segment.source: Image file formats
segment.target: Image file formats

segment.source: Image and ImageBrush can display these image file formats:
segment.target: Image and ImageBrush can display these image file formats:

segment.source: Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)
segment.target: Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)

segment.source: Portable Network Graphics (PNG)
segment.target: Portable Network Graphics (PNG)

segment.source: bitmap (BMP)
segment.target: bitmap (BMP)

segment.source: Graphics Interchange Format (GIF)
segment.target: Graphics Interchange Format (GIF)

segment.source: Tagged Image File Format (TIFF)
segment.target: Tagged Image File Format (TIFF)

segment.source: JPEG XR
segment.target: JPEG XR

segment.source: icons (ICO)
segment.target: icons (ICO)

segment.source: The APIs for Image, BitmapImage and BitmapSource don't include any dedicated methods for encoding and decoding of media formats.
segment.target: The APIs for Image, BitmapImage and BitmapSource don't include any dedicated methods for encoding and decoding of media formats.

segment.source: All of the encode and decode operations are built-in, and at most will surface aspects of encode or decode as part of event data for load events.
segment.target: All of the encode and decode operations are built-in, and at most will surface aspects of encode or decode as part of event data for load events.

segment.source: If you want to do any special work with image encode or decode, which you might use if your app is doing image conversions or manipulation, you should use the APIs that are available in the Windows.Graphics.Imaging namespace.
segment.target: If you want to do any special work with image encode or decode, which you might use if your app is doing image conversions or manipulation, you should use the APIs that are available in the Windows.Graphics.Imaging namespace.

segment.source: These APIs are also supported by the Windows Imaging Component (WIC) in Windows.
segment.target: These APIs are also supported by the Windows Imaging Component (WIC) in Windows.

segment.source: For more info about app resources and how to package image sources in an app, see Defining app resources.
segment.target: For more info about app resources and how to package image sources in an app, see Defining app resources.

segment.source: WriteableBitmap
segment.target: WriteableBitmap

segment.source: A WriteableBitmap provides a BitmapSource that can be modified and that doesn't use the basic file-based decoding from the WIC.
segment.target: A WriteableBitmap provides a BitmapSource that can be modified and that doesn't use the basic file-based decoding from the WIC.

segment.source: You can alter images dynamically and re-render the updated image.
segment.target: You can alter images dynamically and re-render the updated image.

segment.source: To define the buffer content of a WriteableBitmap, use the PixelBuffer property to access the buffer and use a stream or language-specific buffer type to fill it.
segment.target: To define the buffer content of a WriteableBitmap, use the PixelBuffer property to access the buffer and use a stream or language-specific buffer type to fill it.

segment.source: For example code, see WriteableBitmap.
segment.target: For example code, see WriteableBitmap.

segment.source: RenderTargetBitmap
segment.target: RenderTargetBitmap

segment.source: The RenderTargetBitmap class can capture the XAML UI tree from a running app, and then represents a bitmap image source.
segment.target: The RenderTargetBitmap class can capture the XAML UI tree from a running app, and then represents a bitmap image source.

segment.source: After capture, that image source can be applied to other parts of the app, saved as a resource or app data by the user, or used for other scenarios.
segment.target: After capture, that image source can be applied to other parts of the app, saved as a resource or app data by the user, or used for other scenarios.

segment.source: One particularly useful scenario is creating a runtime thumbnail of a XAML page for a navigation scheme, such as providing an image link from a Hub control.
segment.target: One particularly useful scenario is creating a runtime thumbnail of a XAML page for a navigation scheme, such as providing an image link from a Hub control.

segment.source: RenderTargetBitmap does have some limitations on the content that will appear in the captured image.
segment.target: RenderTargetBitmap does have some limitations on the content that will appear in the captured image.

segment.source: For more info, see the API reference topic for RenderTargetBitmap.
segment.target: For more info, see the API reference topic for RenderTargetBitmap.

segment.source: Image sources and scaling
segment.target: Image sources and scaling

segment.source: You should create your image sources at several recommended sizes, to ensure that your app looks great when Windows scales it.
segment.target: You should create your image sources at several recommended sizes, to ensure that your app looks great when Windows scales it.

segment.source: When specifying a Source for an Image, you can use a naming convention that will automatically reference the correct resource for the current scaling.
segment.target: When specifying a Source for an Image, you can use a naming convention that will automatically reference the correct resource for the current scaling.

segment.source: For specifics of the naming convention and more info, see Quickstart: Using file or image resources.
segment.target: For specifics of the naming convention and more info, see Quickstart: Using file or image resources.

segment.source: For more info about how to design for scaling, see UX guidelines for layout and scaling.
segment.target: For more info about how to design for scaling, see UX guidelines for layout and scaling.

segment.source: Image and ImageBrush in code
segment.target: Image and ImageBrush in code

segment.source: It's typical to specify Image and ImageBrush elements using XAML rather than code.
segment.target: It's typical to specify Image and ImageBrush elements using XAML rather than code.

segment.source: This is because these elements are often the output of design tools as part of a XAML UI definition.
segment.target: This is because these elements are often the output of design tools as part of a XAML UI definition.

segment.source: If you define an Image or ImageBrush using code, use the default constructors, then set the relevant source property (Image.Source or ImageBrush.ImageSource).
segment.target: If you define an Image or ImageBrush using code, use the default constructors, then set the relevant source property (Image.Source or ImageBrush.ImageSource).

segment.source: The source properties require a BitmapImage (not a URI) when you set them using code.
segment.target: The source properties require a BitmapImage (not a URI) when you set them using code.

segment.source: If your source is a stream, use the SetSourceAsync method to initialize the value.
segment.target: If your source is a stream, use the SetSourceAsync method to initialize the value.

segment.source: If your source is a URI, which includes content in your app that uses the ms-appx or ms-resource schemes, use the BitmapImage constructor that takes a URI.
segment.target: If your source is a URI, which includes content in your app that uses the ms-appx or ms-resource schemes, use the BitmapImage constructor that takes a URI.

segment.source: You might also consider handling the ImageOpened event if there are any timing issues with retrieving or decoding the image source, where you might need alternate content to display until the image source is available.
segment.target: You might also consider handling the ImageOpened event if there are any timing issues with retrieving or decoding the image source, where you might need alternate content to display until the image source is available.

segment.source: For example code, see XAML images sample.
segment.target: For example code, see XAML images sample.

segment.source: NoteIf you establish images using code, you can use automatic handling for accessing unqualified resources with current scale and culture qualifiers, or you can use ResourceManager and ResourceMap with qualifiers for culture and scale to obtain the resources directly.
segment.target: NoteIf you establish images using code, you can use automatic handling for accessing unqualified resources with current scale and culture qualifiers, or you can use ResourceManager and ResourceMap with qualifiers for culture and scale to obtain the resources directly.

segment.source: For more info see Resource management system.
segment.target: For more info see Resource management system.
